verses.text: Children, listen to a father’s instruction; pay attention and gain understanding.
verses.comment: The language emphasizes the importance of family and instruction from a spiritual authority. This sets up the theme for the chapter—wisdom passed from one generation to the next, a key pattern for faith continuity (see also Deut. 6:6-9).

verses.text: For I give you good teaching; do not abandon my directions.
verses.comment: The wisdom tradition regards these instructions as more than advice—they are to be treasured and not neglected. Compare the weight placed on apostolic teaching in the early Church (see 2 Thess. 2:15).

verses.text: For when I was a son to my father, tender and the only one in the sight of my mother,
verses.comment: The speaker highlights personal experience, rooting wisdom in parental love and closeness—this points to the authority of tradition and the received faith (cf. 2 Tim. 1:5).

verses.text: he taught me and said to me, “Let your heart hold fast my words; keep my commandments, and you will live.”
verses.comment: Obedience to commandments is connected to life itself, echoing the covenant promises in Deut. 30:15-20. There is an implication of blessing for those who remain faithful.

verses.text: Get wisdom! Get understanding! Do not forget, and do not turn away from the words of my mouth.
verses.comment: The repeated imperative stresses the active pursuit of wisdom. Wisdom here is portrayed as a gift to be received and a goal to seek, preparing for spiritual maturity.

verses.text: Do not abandon her, and she will protect you; love her, and she will watch over you.
verses.comment: Wisdom is personified as a woman who shields and preserves, paralleling descriptions of divine protection (see Sir. 4:11-18). Loving wisdom connects to loving God Himself, the source of all truth.

verses.text: The beginning of wisdom is this: Get wisdom; though it costs all you have, get understanding.
verses.comment: The verse emphasizes the supreme value of wisdom, reflecting Jesus’ parables about the pearl of great price (Matt. 13:45-46).

verses.text: Prize her highly, and she will exalt you; she will honor you if you embrace her.
verses.comment: Honoring wisdom leads to exaltation, echoing Christ’s own words about humility leading to exaltation (Luke 14:11).

verses.text: She will place on your head a garland of grace; she will give you a crown of glory.”
verses.comment: Imagery of crowns and garlands is common for eternal reward, linking to Paul’s references to the ‘crown of righteousness’ (2 Tim. 4:8). Receiving wisdom is equated with receiving heavenly blessing.

verses.text: Listen, my son, and accept my words, that the years of your life may be many.
verses.comment: A promise of long life through obedience reflects the commandment ‘Honor your father and mother’—which Paul notes is ‘the first commandment with a promise’ (Eph. 6:2).

verses.text: I guide you in the way of wisdom and lead you along straight paths.
verses.comment: The concept of the ‘straight path’ anticipates the language of preparing the way for the Lord (Isa. 40:3; Luke 3:4).

verses.text: When you walk, your steps will not be hindered; when you run, you will not stumble.
verses.comment: God’s guidance ensures stability and safety—echoed often in the Psalms when the Lord establishes a person’s steps (cf. Ps. 37:23-24).

verses.text: Hold on to instruction; do not let go. Guard her, for she is your life.
verses.comment: Wisdom is vital for life itself, reflecting the role of the Word of God (see Deut. 8:3, echoed by Jesus in Matt. 4:4).

verses.text: Do not enter the path of the wicked, and do not walk in the way of evil people.
verses.comment: Separation from evil is a fundamental command—compare the call in Psalm 1 to avoid the counsel of the wicked.

verses.text: Avoid it; do not go on it. Turn aside from it and pass by.
verses.comment: This conveys the idea of deliberate avoidance of sin, paralleling New Testament exhortations to ‘flee’ from evil (see 1 Tim. 6:11).

verses.text: For they cannot sleep unless they do evil; they are robbed of sleep unless they make someone stumble.
verses.comment: Evil is described as habitual—unrepentant sinners grow restless apart from wrongdoing, foreshadowing Jesus’ warnings against hardness of heart (Matt. 13:15).

verses.text: For they eat the bread of wickedness and drink the wine of violence.
verses.comment: The metaphor parallels Eucharistic imagery, though here relating to sin. The spiritual food of the faithful is contrasted with the ‘bread and wine’ of iniquity.

verses.text: But the path of the righteous is like the light of dawn, shining brighter and brighter until full day.
verses.comment: The righteous walk ever toward greater light. This anticipates Christ as the ‘light of the world’ (John 8:12), whose followers are also called to shine before others.

verses.text: The way of the wicked is like deep darkness; they do not know over what they stumble.
verses.comment: Moral blindness is a theme picked up in Jesus’ warnings about walking in darkness (John 12:35) and spiritual blindness (Matt. 15:14).

verses.text: My son, be attentive to my words; incline your ear to my sayings.
verses.comment: The persistent call to listen closely reveals the importance of hearing and keeping tradition, much like the idea of handing down the faith (2 Tim. 2:2).

verses.text: Do not let them escape from your sight; keep them within your heart.
verses.comment: Keeping the words in one’s heart prefigures the call to cherish God’s Word deeply—the interiorization of truth prepares the soul for wisdom and holiness.

verses.text: For they are life to those who find them, and health to all their flesh.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings wholeness of life, both spiritual and physical—a holistic vision paralleling later Christian theology’s emphasis on the salvation of the whole person.

verses.text: Guard your heart above all else, for from it flow the springs of life.
verses.comment: The heart is the wellspring of thoughts and behaviors (cf. Matt. 15:18-19). In Christian tradition, guarding the heart is central to spiritual life and virtue.

verses.text: Put away from you a deceitful mouth, and remove perverse speech far from you.
verses.comment: Purity of speech is vital for holiness (see James 3:9-12). Constant discipline over the tongue is a mark of spiritual maturity.

verses.text: Let your eyes look directly ahead; fix your gaze straight in front of you.
verses.comment: Single-mindedness is urged; Jesus echoes this, saying that no one who looks back is fit for the kingdom of God (Luke 9:62). Perseverance in righteousness is ideal.

verses.text: Consider carefully the path of your feet, and all your ways will be established.
verses.comment: Deliberate reflection on one’s journey and choices is key: see how God’s Word ‘is a lamp to my feet’ (Ps. 119:105).

verses.text: Do not turn to the right or to the left; turn your foot away from evil.
verses.comment: Faithfulness and constancy in the moral path are called for; there is value in remaining on the straight and narrow way, which is ultimately fulfilled in following Christ, the Way, the Truth, and the Life (John 14:6).
